BOK stuck in bind between slowdown, US Fed's rate hike

By Park Hyong-ki

Bank of Korea Governor Lee Ju-yeol checks key data on his laptop before holding the central bank's monetary policy meeting in Seoul, Thursday.

/ Korea Times U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen speaks at a press conference after announcing that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in Washington, Wednesday. This is only the second interest rate increase since June 2006.

/ EPA-Yonhap

The U.S. Federal Reserve's rate hike and warnings of more hikes next year are heightening concerns that the upward rate spiral might light the fuse of the record household debt bomb here.

The Fed's tightening of its monetary policy could throw the nation into a more vicious cycle where households spend less due to their growing burden of debt payment, companies slash their investment further, and exports continue to fall on weaker global demand, leaving the economy mired in weaker, jobless growth.

The Bank of Korea (BOK) kept its key rate unchanged at 1.25 percent for this month, Thursday, after the U.S. Fed raised its rate by 25 basis points to 0.5-0.75 percent. The Fed said it will carry out further rate hikes — up to three — next year.

BOK Governor Lee Ju-yeol said the central bank will put a priority on risk management amid growing internal and external uncertainties.

"We've decided to keep the key rate unchanged due to uncertainty, currency volatility and the household debt," BOK Governor Lee told the press. "It is important to manage risks as financial instability would affect growth and inflation."

The central bank would also be reluctant to raise its interest rate following that of the Federal Reserve as that would further negatively affect the country's household debt, he said.

Lee said a series of steps led by the government to contain snowballing household debt, which hit 1,300 trillion won ($1.13 trillion), have failed to keep the lid on the debt growth.

The Bank of Korea (BOK) is stuck in a bind between a slowdown in the economy and the U.S. Federal Reserve's rate hikes, which could light the fuse of the record household debt bomb here.

The Fed's tightening of its monetary policy could throw the nation into a more vicious cycle where households spend less due to their growing burden of debt payment, companies slash their investment further, and exports continue to fall on weaker global demand, leaving the economy mired in weaker, jobless growth.

The BOK kept its key rate unchanged at 1.25 percent for this month, Thursday, after the U.S. Fed raised its rate by 25 basis points to 0.5-0.75 percent. The Fed said it will carry out further rate hikes — up to three — next year.

BOK Governor Lee Ju-yeol said the central bank will prioritize risk management amid growing internal and external uncertainties.

Lee said a series of steps led by the government to contain snowballing household debt, which hit 1,300 trillion won ($1.13 trillion), have failed to keep the lid on the debt growth.

The Fed's rate hike comes as the government here is struggling to contain household debt, which hit a record high of 1,300 trillion won ($1.13 trillion) as of the third quarter of this year.

President Moon Jae-in's administration has been trying to keep the lid on household debt through a series of steps, including the introduction of a debt management program, which allows indebted households to refinance their loans with the government's help.

The BOK has also been trying to prevent excessive credit growth with its macroprudential policy, which tightens regulations on banks' lending to households.

But the debt-to-disposable income ratio, an important gauge of household debt, hit a record high of 166.1 percent in the third quarter, up 0.3 percentage points from a quarter earlier and 8.3 percentage points from the same period of 2013.

The BOK said it will closely monitor the impact of the U.S. rate hike and the Fed's monetary policy normalization, and make adjustments to its policy if necessary.

The central bank also said it will closely monitor the economy and its risks, such as the household debt and a weakening global economy.
